title: 104_s1857
content: The "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996" establishes the Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices with duties outlined for the Commission. The Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996 establishes the Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices to study and make recommendations for changes to laws and regulations affecting Federal election campaigns. The Commission will consider issues such as campaign financing, qualifications of candidates, trust in the political process, media access, and other relevant matters. The Commission shall consist of 9 private sector members appointed by various officials. A chairperson will be selected by majority vote within 7 days of all members being appointed, with a 30-day deadline. Failure to select a chairperson will result in the discharge of all current members. The office of chairperson is vacant, leading to the discharge of all current members of the Commission. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Each member is entitled to compensation based on the annual rate of basic pay. A quorum of six members is required for decisions, and meetings will be called by the chairperson or at the request of six members. The chairperson can appoint staff without following standard hiring procedures. The Commission can recommend fast track procedures. The Commission must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the 105th Congress convening, detailing their study. The report may include recommendations for changes in laws governing Federal campaigns. If 7 or more members agree on a recommendation, they must prepare a bill for each recommendation to be expedited for consideration by Congress. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report. $750,000 is authorized for carrying out the Act.
